subject: Re: [junit] Can anyone help me see how to usefully work with JUnit in a big project, please?
msgSnippet: On 10/25/06, Tracey Annison  wrote:  ...  ...  Hi, I have selectively responded to the paragraph I can offer input to;
messageBody:
On 10/25/06, Tracey Annison <TAnnison@...> wrote:
<SNIP>
>
> I've been having a browse around, but I don't seem to see anyone with
> the same questions as me... which is probably a sign that I'm on the
> wrong track somehow! :)
<SNIP>
>... the start, and a setUp method of 400 lines or more as well. To test
> one Service (under 2,000 lines of code for 7 methods using 80
> properties) that simply offers a standard set of
> Get/Create/Update/Delete methods on an entity, the tests run over 5
> files to a total length of 30,000 lines! In order to get test
> coverage above 80%, there's a large amount of test code that simply
> checks that the gets/sets work... which most of the time they can't
> help but do anyway.
</SNIP>

Hi,

I have selectively responded to the paragraph I can offer input to;
hope thats OK :-)

Regarding he getters/setters testing, some believe it is trivial, but
I've been burned too many times to not do it. You don't have to do
it... until you do ;-) To ease the pain - try to implement/utilise
TestUtil from
http://gtcgroup.com/util/
then one line of code tests your accessors.

The other thing that strikes me in this paragraph of your post, was
that these classes/methods are perhaps rather large. Most TDD methods
are short and succint, five to 10 lines. It appears as if there is a
fear of adding methods or classes here, or perhaps that your workplace
is not doing TDD, but adding tests after the fact to get code coverage
up to pass QA. In my experince TDD lends itself to nice short
testable methods. A really good example of this, (short methods), in
a large system is to look at any smalltalk image, (which I'm guessing
you will be able to browse and and get the gist of the unfamiliar
code) - perhaps Squeak
http://www.squeak.org - very few of the entire systems methods fall
into the size you describe.

As you have good tests already, heavy refactoring, (Extract Method),
before changing any code may be the way to ease the load, the amount
of code under test, and the amount of setup required.

Regards,
Chris
